case_name: Licensing Authority under the Imports Exports Control Act, 1947 v. Lala Manickchand, proprietor of Messrs Katrella Metal Corporation

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 25, 1971 of the Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 120 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 1971 of the Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 120 of 1971. S. Desai, M. C. Bhandere and S. P. Nayar, for the appellant.

facts.text: Madras High Court dismissed Writ Appeal No. 120 of 1971 at admission stage on March 25, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment and order of the Madras High Court dated March 25, 1971 dismissing at the stage of admission an appeal under cl.  15  of the Letters Patent

facts.text: Learned single Judge of Madras High Court allowed writ petition No. 933 of 1970 on September 1, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: preferred by the appellant against the judgment and order of a learned single Judge of that Court dated September 1, 1970 allowing writ petition number 933 of 1970 filed by the respondent

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition No. 933 of 1970 praying for writ of mandamus directing Licensing Authority to consider applications for import licence.

anchor.surface_text: praying for a writ of mandamus directing the Licensing Authority under the Imports Exports  Control  Act, 1947 to do his public duty and companysider the applications for import licence made by the respondent.

facts.text: On December 7, 1968, Lala Manickchand, proprietor of Messrs Katrella Metal Corporation, Madras, submitted application for import licence for Rs. 9,900 for stainless steel as actual user for manufacturing hospital requisites.

anchor.surface_text: On December 7, 1968 Lala Manickchand, proprietor of Messrs Katrella Metal Corporation, Madras, respondent in this Court, submitted an application, as a new unit, for the licensing period,1968-69

facts.text: Registration certificate dated December 31, 1968 issued to respondent as small scale industry by Additional Assistant Director of Industries Commerce, District Madras North.

anchor.surface_text: According to Import Trade Control Policy  1968-69  indus- tries engaged in the manufacture of medical and surgical equipment and appliances were included in the list of priority

facts.text: Licensing Instruction No. 4/69 issued on January 30, 1969 directing scrutiny of applications from newcomer units for stainless steel.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime on January 30, 1969 Licensing Instruction No. 4/69 was issued from the Iron and Steel Control Department  I E Division .

facts.text: Chief Controller issued General Licensing Instruction No. 29/69 on May 19, 1969 clarifying priority for hospital equipment.

anchor.surface_text: On May 19, 1969 the Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, from the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Supply issued General Licensing Instruction No. 29/69

facts.text: General Licensing Instruction No. 31/69 issued on May 29, 1969 listing end-products for priority industries.

anchor.surface_text: On May 29, 1969 the Chief Controller of Imports and Exports issued General Licensing Instruction No. 31 of 1969 on the subject of grant of import licence

facts.text: Director of Industries, Madras confirmed Essentiality Certificate to respondent on October 31, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: On October 31, 1969 the Director of Industries, Madras, companyfirmed the Essentiality Certificate already issued to the respondent.

facts.text: Director of Industries recommended on February 23, 1970 treating respondent as PRIORITY INDUSTRY for import licence.

anchor.surface_text: On February 23, 1970 a letter was written by the Director of Industries and Commerce, Madras to the Deputy Assistant Iron Steel Con- troller, Madras,

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition on March 30, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: It was in these circumstances that the respondent filed the writ petition in the High Court on March 30, 1970 claiming a writ of mandamus

facts.text: Firm manufacturing various items since 1962 with annual turnover of 8 to 10 lacs from local raw material.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondents case in the High Court, the firms factory had-been manufacturing various items since 1962 by purchasing raw material

facts.text: Chief Controller letter dated 8-4-1970 provides applications received in time may be considered irrespective of forwarding date in terms of 1970-71 policy.

anchor.surface_text: However, instructions have since been received vide the Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, New Delhi letter dated 8-4-1970,

facts.text: Single Judge directed Licensing Authority to consider applications applying 1968-69 or 1969-70 policy within six months.

facts.text: Division Bench dismissed appeal on March 25, 1971 extending time by three months.

anchor.surface_text: On this view the appeal was dismissed but time for granting the import licence was extended by a further period of three months from the date

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal directing consideration under 1970-71 policy.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly allow the appeal with the observation that the respondents application be companysidered in accordance with the import policy

facts.text: Stainless steel sheets became canalised item for non-priority industries under 1970-71 policy.

anchor.surface_text: According to policy for 1970-71, the material stainless steel sheets is a canalised item for number-priority industries

anchor.surface_text: It has companye to the numberice of the Iron Steel Controller that a large number of applications have been received for import of Stainless Steel

arguments.claim: Applications for import licences must be considered in terms of the relevant policy in force at the time of making the application, per r.7(2) Chapter II of Import Trade Control Handbook 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Relying on r. 7 2 in Chapter 11 of the Handbook of Rules of Procedure, Import Trade Control for the year 1968, according to which applications for licences were required to be considered in terms of the relevant policy in force, the learned single Judge directed that the Licensing Authority do consider the applications now pending before him which are the subject matter of these writ petitions within six months from this date bearing in mind the above directions and in particular deal with the said applications, applying the import trade control policy prevailing in 1968-69 or 1969-70, as the case may be according to the dates of application for licence.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n April, 1969 the Department companysidered it desirable to have a further scrutiny and fresh instructions came into force with effect from April 16,

arguments.court_reasoning: No undue delay by department; no vested right to policy at application time; consider under policy at grant time.

arguments.claim: Department cannot take advantage of its own delay in processing applications by applying later canalisation policy.

anchor.surface_text: The division Bench did not consider this objection to be valid because in its view had the applications been considered in time and without delay and the import licence sought granted, these complications would not have intervened. The Department, according to the High Court, could not take advantage of the delay in disposing of the applications for licence made earlier and then take the plea that they should be disposed of only in accordance with the current policy and instructions given as to canalisation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: our opinion this was number unreasonable. It was on April 8, 1970 that the Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, apparently after proper review of

arguments.court_reasoning: No undue delay, laches or dilatoriness by Department.

arguments.claim: No absolute right to import licence merely on sponsoring authority recommendation; licensing authority can refuse under s.3(1)(a) Imports & Exports Control Act 1947 and cl.6(1)(a) Imports Control Order 1955 if no forex, prejudicial to state, or canalised.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants learned counsel Shri V. S. Desai at the outset drew our attention to s. 3 1 a of the Imports Exports Control Act, 18 of 1947 which empowers the Central Government to prohibit, restrict or otherwise control imports and exports and to cl. 6 1 a of the Imports Control Order, 1 9 5 5 made by the Central Government in exercise of the powers conferred on it by ss. 3 and 4 of Act 18 of 1947.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ry of the 1968-69 period, and we are assuming without holding, that the respondents application had reached the appropriate authority during the 1968-

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirms discretionary power of licensing authority considering forex, economy, canalisation.

arguments.claim: For back period licences, consider merits including forex availability, indigenous sources, essentiality at time of consideration, per para 91 Chapter IV Import Trade Control Handbook 1968.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection refe- rence was also made to para 91. of Chapter IV of the Import Trade Control Handbook of Rules and Procedure 1968 which reads Issue of import licences to actual users for back period 91 I Where an application for import licence from an actual user is not disposed of during the licensing period concerned on account of any delay or laches on the part of the applicant, no licence against such application will be issued after the expiry of the licensing period or after the close of the monetary ceiling.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ry of the 1968-69 period, and we are assuming without holding, that the respondents application had reached the appropriate authority during the 1968-

arguments.court_reasoning: Supports consideration under current conditions at grant time.

arguments.claim: Canalisation of imports through specialised agencies is in public interest; refusal outside channels valid, per Glass Chatons Importers case.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Desai in support of his submission relied on the following observations from the decision of this Court in Glass Chatons Importers and Users Association v. Union of India 1 It is obvious that if a decision has been made that imports shall be by particular agencies or channels the granting of licence to any applicant outside the agency or channel would frustrate the implementation of that decision.

arguments.court_reasoning: Canalisation policy applies; stainless steel canalised for non-priority under 1970-71.

arguments.claim: Sponsoring authority recommendation (Director of Industries letter Feb 23, 1970) entitles to licence as priority industry under 1968-69 policy; canalisation post-dates case completion.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Singhvi on behalf of the respondent controverted the appellants argument by strongly relying on the letter dated February 23, 1 970 from the Director of Industries to the Deputy Assistant Iron and Steel Controller in which reference was made to the respondents assurance to manufacture only surgical equipments like sterlisers, operation tables, autoclaves etc. and it was recommended that import of stainless steel sheets for the period 1968-69 be treated as priority industry and licence issued to the respondent on this basis.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n April, 1969 the Department companysidered it desirable to have a further scrutiny and fresh instructions came into force with effect from April 16,

arguments.court_reasoning: No absolute right; consider under policy at grant time.

arguments.claim: Applications to be considered under policy at time of application, per r.7(2) Handbook 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Singhvi placed strong reliance on r-. 7 2 contained in the Import Trade Control Handbook of Rules and Procedure of 1968 and contended that the applications for licences must be considered in tern-is of the relevant policy in force at the time of making the application.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n April, 1969 the Department companysidered it desirable to have a further scrutiny and fresh instructions came into force with effect from April 16,

arguments.court_reasoning: Policy at grant time governs due to changing forex, economy.

arguments.claim: Licensing authority must issue on basis of sponsoring recommendation per r.81(c), give due consideration per r.80 Handbook.

anchor.surface_text: Reference in this connection was also made to r. 81 c , according to which the role of the licensing authorities is To issue licences on the basis of the recommendations of the sponsoring authorities where such recommendations are in consonance with the policy procedure in force... The learned counsel submitted that the recommendation of the sponsoring authority has to be given due consideration by the licensing authority as provided in r. 80.

arguments.court_reasoning: Due consideration but not binding; discretionary refusal possible.

arguments.claim: 163 other applicants similarly placed granted licences worth Rs.9900 each in March 1969, discriminatory violating natural justice and equality.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents learned counsel also submitted that about 163 applications for import licence,, had been dealt with by the licensing authority and the licences granted to the applicants. Reference in this connection was made to the affidavit of Lala Manickchand filed in the High Court... These licences, according to the assertion in this paragraph, had been granted without any basis, though a little lower down it was added that those applicants were similarly placed as the respondent and, therefore, the issue of import licence to them showed discriminatory conduct violative of rules of natural justice and equality.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . As per policy, there was a ban on issue of licences for stainless steel sheets for manufacture of household utensils. It was in May. 1969 after the

arguments.court_reasoning: Insufficient material on record; no prima facie case of discrimination or mala fides.

arguments.claim: New units procedure under para 82(2) Handbook; first/second applications through sponsoring authority.

anchor.surface_text: It may be recalled that the respondent applied for the licence ,I, a new unit. Para 82, sub-para 2 contained in the Handbook of Rules and Procedure for 1968 provides 82 2 New Units Priority industries a The new units, both in the large and the small scale sectors, should make their first and second import applications for raw materials and components in a licensing period, through the sponsoring authority concerned, each covering their requirements for six months.

arguments.claim: No undue delay or laches by Department; application not disposed due to scrutiny needs for sensitive item, incomplete end-use info.

anchor.surface_text: It is not possible for us, on the material on the record and on the arguments advanced at the bar, to hold that there was any undue delay, laches or dilatoriness on the part of the Department in disposing of the respondents application during 1968-69.

arguments.qualifiers: on the material on the record

arguments.claim: No case for mandamus to consider under 1968-69 policy; no vested right to specific policy.
Applications like respondent's to be considered under 1970-71 policy per Chief Controller instructions April 8, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: However, instructions have since been received vide the Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, New Delhi letter dated 8-4-1970, which inter alia provides that applications received by the sponsoring authorities in time may be considered irrespective of the date on which they were forwarded to the licensing authorities and in terms of the licensing policy for 1970-71.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: pondent was naturally required to companyply with these instructions. Since the respondents application companytained items which were number- priorit

arguments.claim: Mala fides or arbitrariness not argued in HC, cannot be entertained without HC opinion.

anchor.surface_text: No point of mala fides or arbitrariness was argued in the High Court and no serious attempt was made on behalf of the respondent to sustain the impugned order of the High Court on that basis, as indeed, it is not possible for this Court to entertain and adjudicate upon such a plea in this appeal in the absence of a considered opinion of the High Court.

arguments.claim: Speedy disposal important but provisions like paras 302-304 Handbook check delays; no undue delay here.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that speedy disposal of applications for import licences is of the greatest importance. Indeed, in the Import Trade Control Handbook of Rules and Procedure, 1968 paras 302 to 304 have been exclusively devoted to the subject of Checks on delays.

holdings.text: the respondent has no absolute right to the grant of a licence merely because his application has been recommended by the sponsoring authority and that the licensing authority may decline to grant the licence on other relevant considerations affecting the larger and more vital interests of the economy of the State

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of these provisions, according to the submission, suggests that the respondent has no absolute right to the grant of a licence merely because his application has been recommended by the sponsoring authority and that the licensing authority may decline to grant the licence on other relevant considerations affecting the larger and more vital interests of the economy of the State and also other relevant factors beyond the control of the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Imports & Exports Control Act s.3(1)(a) and Imports Control Order cl.6(1)(a) empowers refusal based on forex availability, state interest, canalisation despite recommendation

holdings.text: if availability of the goods applied for, from indigenous sources, improves or the position in regard to foreign exchange deteriorates or there is a change in the matter of essentiality of the goods applied for, then, it would be and, indeed, it should be open to the licensing authority to come to a fresh decision on the question of issuing the licence uninfluenced by the consideration that during the previous licensing period the situation being more easy, the import licence applied for would have been more readily granted

anchor.surface_text: These considerations, said Shri Desai, indicate that if availability of the goods applied for, from indigenous sources, improves or the position in regard to foreign exchange deteriorates or there is a change in the matter of essentiality of the goods applied for, then, it would be and, indeed, it should be open to the licensing authority to come to a fresh decision on the question of issuing the licence uninfluenced by the consideration that during the previous licensing period the situation being more easy, the import licence applied for would have been more readily granted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Para 91 Import Handbook for back period licences requires consideration of current merits including forex, indigenous availability, essentiality at time of consideration

holdings.text: canalization of imports is in the interests of the general public the refusal of imports licences to applicants outside the agencies or channels decided upon must necessarily be held also in the interests of the general public

anchor.surface_text: Shri Desai in support of his submission relied on the following observations from the decision of this Court in Glass Chatons Importers and Users Association v. Union of India 1 It is obvious that if a decision has been made that imports shall be by particular agencies or channels the granting of licence to any applicant outside the agency or channel would frustrate the implementation of that decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent from Glass Chatons: canalisation through agencies serves public interest including economy, trade, monetary policy

holdings.text: No point of mala fides or arbitrariness was argued in the High Court and no serious attempt was made on behalf of the respondent to sustain the impugned order of the High Court on that basis, as indeed, it is not possible for this Court to entertain and adjudicate upon such a plea in this appeal in the absence of a considered opinion of the High Court

anchor.surface_text: No point of mala fides or arbitrariness was argued in the High Court and no serious attempt was made on behalf of the respondent to sustain the impugned order of the High Court on that basis, as indeed, it is not possible for this Court to entertain and adjudicate upon such a plea in this appeal in the absence of a considered opinion of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: plea not raised before High Court, no considered opinion below; Supreme Court cannot entertain first time

holdings.text: The material on the existing record to which our attention was drawn is not enough to make out a prima facie case of either mala fides or arbitrariness to justify any further scrutiny

anchor.surface_text: In our view the plea of arbitrariness and mala fides having not been pressed in the High Court it is not possible for this Court to consider it. The material on the existing record to which our attention was drawn is not enough to make out a prima facie case of either mala fides or arbitrariness to justify any further scrutiny.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Insufficient evidence on record to establish discrimination or violation of natural justice/equality despite other licences granted

holdings.text: It is not possible for us, on the material on the record and on the arguments advanced at the bar, to hold that there was any undue delay, laches or dilatoriness on the part of the Department in disposing of the respondents application during 1968-69

anchor.surface_text: It is not possible for us, on the material on the record and on the arguments advanced at the bar, to hold that there was any undue delay, laches or dilatoriness on the part of the Department in disposing of the respondents application during 1968-69.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scrutiny required for sensitive item stainless steel due to many newcomer applications; incomplete end-use info; instructions issued timely

holdings.text: In our opinion, no case has been made out on the present record for a mandamus to the Department to consider the respondents application for import licence in terms of 1968-69 policy
holdings.reasoning_summary: No undue delay by department; no vested right to specific policy; writ not grantable to compel under outdated policy

holdings.text: We would accordingly allow the appeal with the observation that the respondents application be considered in accordance with the import policy for the year 1970-71 without avoidable delay

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly allow the appeal with the observation that the respondents application be considered in accordance with the import policy for the year 1970-71 without avoidable delay. In the circumstances of the case there would be no order as to costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reverses High Court direction for 1968-69/69-70 policy; applies policy at grant time per Chief Controller instructions and overall considerations

precedents.citation: Glass Chatons Importers and Users Association v. Union of India 1 ... 1 1962 1. S.C.R. 862 at 866.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Desai in support of his submission relied on the following observations from the decision of this Court in Glass Chatons Importers and Users Association v. Union of India 1 It is obvious that if a decision has been made that imports shall be by particular agencies or channels the granting of licence to any applicant outside the agency or channel would frustrate the implementation of that decision. If therefore a canalization of imports is in the interests of the general public the refusal of imports licences to applicants outside the agencies or channels decided upon must necessarily be held also in the  1  1962 1. S.C.R. 862 at 866.

precedents.case_name: Glass Chatons Importers and Users Association v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Canalization of imports through special or specialized agencies or channels is in the interests of the general public if so decided, and refusal of licences to others outside such channels is valid; import policy forms integral part of economic policy considering various national interests.
precedents.cited_holding: If therefore a canalization of imports is in the interests of the general public the refusal of imports licences to applicants outside the agencies or channels decided upon must necessarily be held also in the interests of the general public.

precedents.citation: Sha Maggajee Saremall Bros v. Joint Chief Controller of Imports and Exports 1 ... A.I.R. 1966 Mad. 309.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Singhvi relied on a decision of the Madras High Court Sha Maggajee Saremall Bros v. Joint Chief Controller of Imports and Exports 1  the head-note of which reads Where a transfer of quota rights is effected as a result of change in the constitution of the firm, the new constituted firm becomes entitled to the transferred quota as from the date on which the reconstitution was effected and not from the date on which the Chief Controller of Imports purports to accord recognition to such reconstitution. The fact that a rule by way of an instruction has been introduced in the Red Book limiting the consideration of applications only to the immediately prior period cannot have any value in so far as the rights of parties come in for examination. The rights of the established importer to the licence for the back periods cannot be denied if his application had been kept pending for reasons other than laches on the part of the applicant. An application for import licence for a particular period must be considered only in the light of the policy relevant to that period and cannot be refused on the basis of a later policy which might have changed the position with regard to the licences for the import of the item applied for. Decision in W.A. No. 15 of 1960  Mad.  and in W.P. Nos. 27, 47, 48 of 1961  Mad.  followed. A.I.R. 1966 Mad. 309.

precedents.case_name: Sha Maggajee Saremall Bros v. Joint Chief Controller of Imports and Exports
precedents.cited_proposition: An application for import licence for a particular period must be considered only in the light of the policy relevant to that period and cannot be refused on the basis of a later policy.

precedents.citation: The Municipal Corporation for Greater Bombay The Advance Builders India Pvt. Ltd. 1 ... C.A. No. 1121 of 1970 decided on 25th August, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The unreported decision of this Court in The Municipal Corporation for Greater Bombay The Advance Builders India Pvt. Ltd. 1 , also relied upon by Shri Singhvi merely lays down that where a statute imposes a duty the performance or non-performance of which is not a matter of discretion, a mandamus may be granted ordering that to be done which the statute requires to be done  Halsburys Laws of England, Third edn. Vol. II, p. 90  . Quite clearly, this decision only reiterates the recognised rule in regard to the grant of mandamus and is of little help to the respondent. C.A. No. 1121 of 1970 decided on 25th August, 1971.

precedents.case_name: Municipal Corporation for Greater Bombay v. Advance Builders India Pvt. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Where a statute imposes a duty the performance or non-performance of which is not a matter of discretion, a mandamus may be granted ordering that to be done which the statute requires to be done.

anchor.surface_text: These considerations, said Shri Desai, indicate that if availability of the goods applied for, from indigenous sources, improves or the position in regard to foreign exchange deteriorates or there is a change in the matter of essentiality of the goods applied for, then, it would be and, indeed, it should be open to the licensing authority to come to a fresh decision on the question of issuing the licence uninfluenced by the consideration that during the previous licensing period the situation being more easy, the import licence applied for would have been more readily granted.
